title: 105_hr3573
content: Limitation on disbursements from the Exchange Stabilization Fund to certain countries. Section 5302 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to limit disbursements from the Exchange Stabilization Fund to foreign countries not in compliance with IMF commitments. The Secretary of the Treasury cannot exceed $500,000,000 for international rescue plans unless the country meets IMF reform commitments. The Secretary of the Treasury must consider the total amount of expenditures, loans, obligations, or guarantees made through the stabilization fund for a foreign entity or government within a 6-month period to determine if it exceeds the limitation imposed. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress on US actions to monitor foreign government compliance with commitments made to the IMF in connection with financial assistance packages. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress on US actions to monitor foreign government compliance with commitments made to the IMF in Asia. This includes describing the actions taken by the US Executive Director at the IMF and the Department of the Treasury. The Treasury, in coordination with the Office of the United States Trade Representative or the Department of Commerce, monitors and enforces commitments. The Treasury, in coordination with the Office of the United States Trade Representative or the Department of Commerce, monitors the effects of the Asian Financial Crisis on the United States and other economies. The Commerce Department, in coordination with the United States Trade Representative, monitors Asian countries' compliance with international agreements on market access for foreign goods and services. Reports are submitted to Congress every two months until financial assistance is terminated for each country, including progress on resolving trade disputes under section 301(b)(1) of the Trade Act. The Trade Representative identified barriers in Korea denying access to foreign automobiles. Progress on trade obligations with Korea and Indonesia's compliance with ending the "National Car" program are reported. Implementation of IMF reforms on corporate governance is also assessed. The curr_chunk discusses the need for transparency in corporate practices, independent audits, and no government subsidies to prevent financial failures in specific industries. It also mentions IMF-required reforms for deregulation, privatization, and opening up the economy to foreign investment. The curr_chunk discusses trade policies in Asian countries and the enforcement of obligations under international agreements for market access. The Commerce Department will monitor exports from Asian countries to ensure compliance. The Commerce Department will monitor exports from Asian countries receiving financial assistance to ensure market access compliance. Actions will be taken to open markets for exports from these countries to share the burden of the financial crisis in Asia. The Commerce Department will monitor Asian countries' exports to the US for any significant increase due to currency fluctuations, subsidies, or dumping. Reports will be submitted to Congress every two months until financial assistance is terminated, with appropriate actions taken under US laws if necessary. The Secretary of Commerce will consult with import-sensitive US industries to share relevant information and views for monitoring and reporting on dumping or subsidization causing injury. An annual report to Congress will assess the impact of financial assistance on trade relations between Asian countries and others. SEC. 4. FULL ENFORCEMENT OF TRADE LAW REMEDIES. The Secretary of Commerce will conduct a study with import-sensitive US industries to determine the application of antidumping and countervailing duty laws to imports from Asian countries affected by currency devaluations and financial assistance. The study will address rapid fluctuations in exchange rates to prevent undermining US antidumping laws. The Secretary of Commerce will conduct a study on the application of antidumping and countervailing duty laws to imports from Asian countries affected by currency devaluations and financial assistance. The study will determine appropriate treatment under US countervailing duty laws for subsidies received in the past, even if companies have been sold or privatized. The Secretary will report to Congress within 6 months of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. SUNSET. The provisions of this Act will end 8 years after its enactment.
